title: 107_hr1167
content: The Act titled "Comprehensive Tuberculosis Elimination Act of 2001" includes a section on interagency collaboration for tuberculosis elimination, establishing a committee for this purpose. The Comprehensive Tuberculosis Elimination Act of 2001 establishes the Committee on Interagency Collaboration for Tuberculosis Elimination, which advises the Secretary of Health and Human Services on coordinating federal efforts to eliminate tuberculosis. The Committee considers recommendations from the Institute of Medicine and develops a national plan in consultation with public and private stakeholders. The Committee advises on developing a national plan for tuberculosis training and education, as well as a global plan for US involvement in tuberculosis control activities. The Committee focuses on high-burden countries and access to DOTS. It is composed of representatives from various federal departments and agencies, as well as appointed members. Definitions include the Committee and the Secretary. The Public Health Service Act is amended to establish a national program for tuberculosis elimination. The Public Health Service Act is amended to establish a national program for tuberculosis elimination, including research, demonstration projects, education, and training focused on diagnosis, treatment, drug-resistant strains, specific populations, and clinical trials. The Public Health Service Act is amended to establish a national program for tuberculosis elimination, including research, prevention, control, and collaboration with Immigration and Naturalization Service to identify and treat immigrants with tuberculosis infection. This includes public information and education programs, training for health professionals, support for model centers, and collaboration with international organizations and foreign countries. The Council is required to submit annual reports to Congress and the Secretary on activities related to tuberculosis. The report should include the Council's opinion on the implementation of recommendations from the Institute of Medicine. Authorization of appropriations is set at $528,000,000 for fiscal year 2002, with additional funding as needed for fiscal years 2003 through 2006. The National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute's activities related to tuberculosis are amended in the Public Health Service Act. Authorization of appropriations is set at $528,000,000 for fiscal year 2002, with additional funding as needed for fiscal years 2003 through 2006. The Director of the Institute will expand research on tuberculosis, including efforts to eliminate the disease. Activities will focus on enhancing basic and clinical research, as well as studying the relationship between tuberculosis and HIV. The Institute may provide awards to faculty to develop curricula aimed at increasing opportunities for interested individuals. The Director of the Institute may provide awards to support career development for professionals committed to research on pulmonary infections and tuberculosis. Authorization of appropriations includes $5,000,000 for tuberculosis academic awards for fiscal year 2002 and funding for fiscal years 2003 through 2006. For tuberculosis/pulmonary infection awards, $5,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2002, with additional funding for fiscal years 2003 through 2006. SEC. 302. ACTIVITIES OF NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES. Section 447A of the Public Health Service Act is amended to include activities for developing a tuberculosis vaccine, following a blueprint from a 1998 workshop. Funding of $240,000,000 for fiscal year 2002 is also specified. Funding of $240,000,000 is allocated for fiscal year 2002, with additional funding for fiscal years 2003 through 2006 as needed. SEC. 303. JOHN E. FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCED STUDY IN THE HEALTH SCIENCES. The Public Health Service Act is amended to expand international activities for tuberculosis research and training through the John E. Fogarty International Center. The John E. Fogarty International Center expands international activities for tuberculosis research and training, modeled after the international training program for the human immunodeficiency virus. The Public Health Service Act is amended to include loan repayment programs for research on tuberculosis. The Secretary is required to reserve a portion of funds for contracts to conduct tuberculosis research.
